I was

didn't go until I was

it was um it was definitely great now I

and you see the quality of Marines
across the generations and and it really
starts at uh at boot camp I always say
the biggest thing they teach you which
to most people wouldn't matter is like
you got to tie shoot your bootlaces left
over right they teach you all the little
small details so that that's what you
pay attention to what the why am I
wasting my time my boot laac at but they
they teach you to be precise on

these guys are a lot sharper than

I did my first tour in Afghanistan it
was kind of strange for then we were
still peacetime military and uh we
didn't have big budgets um that's why
you see a lot of stuff in like the
series where people complain about
batteries and not having equipment
Afghanistan our team we had one set of
night vision for the entire team we went
over there with a spotting scope it
called m49 spotting scope I thing was
built in
1949 um you know we we just got m4s that
was a new equipment we had and we were
happy as [ __ ] to have those but I we
didn't have plates we didn't have flax
we didn't have helmets we had to bare
minimum gear but for us that we had
everything we ever needed you know and
uh we started doing reconnaissance um a
place called Camp Rhino and just
punching out doing perimeter security
and kind of I guess really getting our
feet wet to what we're going to do but
it was truly still a very peacetime
military and we're just executing what
we've trained over the past multiple
years the first time I think we we
really saw it was uh an Azar at the
bridge scene but it was kind of weird
for me it was like it actually it's
funny a lot of people refer to watching
a Vietnam movie CU I think it's cuz
Bravo my uh my company was we were stuck
inside we couldn't fire and we were

very surreal because it kind of felt
helpless we had to just sit there and
and couldn't return fire we're punching
up a canal to actually like uh kind of
do um a faint into alar uh algara
and uh we pushed up along the canals and
you can tell the locals everyone was
disappearing out of the cities and uh
right away I had that that intuition
that you know we're going to be in it up
here in a little bit the locals were
telling us that it was unfriendly City
you know everything was saying that
there's going to be a firefight up ahead
and uh right when we rolled into the

pretty much it was kind of like chaos
because it wasn't a conventional
military that we were fighting it wasn't
it wasn't red verse blue it wasn't these
guys that were even very well trained
they were just shooting from the hip
spraying everywhere and I mean if if you
really look at the distance that they're
engaging us and we took one guy got hit
and I think it was from a Ricochet it
was just very untrained military just
just trying to shoot us and it was kind
of we were almost we didn't stop and
engage it was almost for us it was just
a drive by and we drive the only
difference is we are pretty pretty good
Shooters especially at the distance we
were engaging at at 30 yards roughly you
know we were hitting what we were we
wanted to hit and they were hitting
nothing but uh yeah for for us so every
it's funny cuz every firefight you
survive it's kind of like a Snowball
Effect after we survived that it was
like wow they can't hit us and you just
kind of feel more bulletproof and more
confident in your training and and
that's how for us for the progression of
uh that deployment which was roughly

where we really didn't lose anybody and
it just built that confidence that hey
